prompt.clinicalNote: - Female, 22 years old, BMI 40, heavy menstrual bleeding, pelvic pain, 2 prior cesarean sections, PCOS.- Patient, a 22-year-old female with a BMI of 40, presents with heavy menstrual bleeding and pelvic pain, history of 2 cesarean sections, PCOS, and appendectomy. On examination, no palpable masses or tenderness noted, enlarged uterus possibly due to fibroids. Management includes ultrasound for fibroid confirmation, medication for bleeding control, or myomectomy if severe, and addressing PCOS for menstrual cycle regulation. Referral to gynecologist for further evaluation and management.Plan:1. Perform ultrasound to confirm fibroids.2. Consider medication for bleeding control.3. Discuss the possibility of myomectomy if needed.4. Address PCOS for menstrual cycle regulation.5. Refer to a gynecologist for further evaluation and management.
guidelines: Issue 1🗑️RCOG - Birth After Previous Caesarean Section - 2015AlgoApply
Obesity with BMI 40🗑️BJOG - 2018 - Denison - Care of Women with Obesity in PregnancyAlgoApply
Menstrual bleeding and pelvic pain🗑️GTG 2012 - Initial Mx of Chronic Pelvic PainAlgoApply
Possible uterine fibroids🗑️Uptodate - 2025 - Uterine fibroids (leiomyomas) Treatment overview - UpToDateAlgoApply
prompt.prompt: You are provided with the text of a clinical note from a patient encounter and a set of clinical guidelines. Your task is to: 1. Cross-check the clinical note against each provided guideline: 2. Identify areas in the clinical note that do not fully adhere to the guideline recommendations. 3. Note any parts of the note that could be improved based on the guidelines. Include the full text of each guideline in your response: 4. For every guideline you reference, include its complete text. 5. Next to each suggested change, provide a short reference to the guideline (e.g., the guideline's name or identifier). 6. Return the clinical note as HTML-formatted code: The clinical note should be output as valid HTML. Any text in the clinical note that has been adjusted or needs adjustment (in light of the guidelines) should be wrapped in tags (to display in italics). Ensure that the guideline reference appears immediately following the italicized adjustment for clarity. Your final output should therefore contain: The complete text of each guideline used, with clear references. The HTML-formatted clinical note where adjustments appear in italics with the respective guideline reference. For example, in the following clinical note text: Summary: Patient presents with irregular menstrual cycles, intense cramps, and heavier flow, raising concerns for underlying conditions. Body: Patient reports irregular menstrual cycles, increased cramps, and heavier flow. No history of ovarian cysts or endometriosis. Further investigation with pelvic exam and imaging studies is warranted. Perform pelvic exam to assess reproductive organs. Consider imaging studies for detailed evaluation. Discuss family planning goals and contraceptive needs. Collaborate to determine the most appropriate management approach. An adjustement in light of this guideline (Endometriosis: diagnosis and management NICE guideline - https://www.nice.org.uk/guidance/ng73) would be to this sentence Further investigation with pelvic exam and imaging studies is warranted. A family history of endometriosis would make the diagnosis more likely (Endometriosis: diagnosis and management NICE guideline) Here is the note text: - Female, 22 years old, BMI 40, heavy menstrual bleeding, pelvic pain, 2 prior cesarean sections, PCOS.- Patient, a 22-year-old female with a BMI of 40, presents with heavy menstrual bleeding and pelvic pain, history of 2 cesarean sections, PCOS, and appendectomy. On examination, no palpable masses or tenderness noted, enlarged uterus possibly due to fibroids. Management includes ultrasound for fibroid confirmation, medication for bleeding control, or myomectomy if severe, and addressing PCOS for menstrual cycle regulation. Referral to gynecologist for further evaluation and management.Plan:1. Perform ultrasound to confirm fibroids.2. Consider medication for bleeding control.3. Discuss the possibility of myomectomy if needed.4. Address PCOS for menstrual cycle regulation.5. Refer to a gynecologist for further evaluation and management. Here is each guideline with the title followed by the guideline: Issue 1🗑️RCOG - Birth After Previous Caesarean Section - 2015AlgoApply Obesity with BMI 40🗑️BJOG - 2018 - Denison - Care of Women with Obesity in PregnancyAlgoApply Menstrual bleeding and pelvic pain🗑️GTG 2012 - Initial Mx of Chronic Pelvic PainAlgoApply Possible uterine fibroids🗑️Uptodate - 2025 - Uterine fibroids (leiomyomas) Treatment overview - UpToDateAlgoApply
